Review Photo- and electro-catalytic deuteration of feedstock chemicals and pharmaceuticals: A review Wei Ou Chuntian Qiu * Chenliang Su # SZU-NUS Collaborative Center and International Collaborative Laboratory of 2D Materials for Optoelectronic Science and Technology of Ministry of Education, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, Guangdong, China SZU-NUS Collaborative Center and International Collaborative Laboratory of 2D Materials for Optoelectronic Science and Technology of Ministry of Education College of Optoelectronic Engineering Shenzhen University Shenzhen Guangdong 518060 China SZU-NUS Collaborative Center and International Collaborative Laboratory of 2D Materials for Optoelectronic Science and Technology of Ministry of Education, College of Optoelectronic Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, Guangdong, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author Deuterium labeling techniques are widely utilized as efficient tools to study the absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion (ADME) of pharmaceuticals. Moreover, deuterium-labeled drugs are expected to prolong the half-life of drug metabolism, enhance the efficacy of drugs, close metabolic sites, and decrease side effects. Thus, there is a rising demand for the practical construction of deuterium-labeled drugs and their intermediates under mild conditions. This paper timely provides an overview of the recent advances in both photo- and electro-catalytic mild and selective deuteration of fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals with low-cost and sustainable deuterium source. Three types of deuteration strategies are discussed according to the deuteration mode, named deuterium atom transfer strategy, deuterium atom abstraction strategy and deuterated water splitting strategy respectively. The application scope and mechanistic insights are discussed comprehensively. Finally, the perspective on the challenges and future development trends for photo- and electro-catalytic deuteration strategies are also presented. Graphical Abstract Recent advances in photo/electrocatalytic deuteration strategies were summarized and classified as deuterium atom transfer/abstraction and deuterated water splitting to give mechanistic insights and specific horizon for precise construction of valuable deuterated products. Keywords Photocatalysis Electrocatalysis Deuterium-labelled drugs H/D atom transfer Single electron transfer 1 Introduction Isotopic labeling, which involves the integration of a unique marker into a molecule without significantly altering its function is considered to be the most effective method for tracking the movement and change of matter [ 1–3 ]. Harold Clayton Urey, who discovered the isotope of hydrogen, named as deuterium (2H), in 1931, was awarded the Nobel prize in 1934. The abundance of deuterium is only 0.016% in the natural distribution of hydrogen isotopes. Deuterium as a cheaper, safer, and relatively readily accessible labeling alternative to 13C, 14C, and 3H is well exploited by chemists in the elucidation of reaction mechanisms as well in the discovery and modification of pharmaceuticals [ 4 ]. In particular, deuterium labeling techniques are widely utilized as efficient tools to study the absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion (ADME) of pharmaceuticals in the field of biomedicine [ 5 ]. On one hand, deuterium provides high sensitivity and accuracy, fast and convenient testing, and reliable data in the study of clinical pharmacokinetic profiles. On the other hand, deuterium-labeled drugs are expected to prolong the half-life of drug metabolism, enhance the efficacy of drugs, close metabolic sites, and decrease side effects because of the better stability of C–D bonds compared to that of C–H bonds [ 6,7 ]. The first deuteration of bioactive molecules, conducted as early as 1961, was demonstrated to improve the pharmacokinetic profile [ 8 ]. Then, after a long period, the first deuterium-labeled drug, deutetrabenazine (SD-809), approved by the American food and drug administration (FDA) in 2017, triggered a boom in the market for deuterium-labeled drugs [ 9 ]. Recently, many global pharmaceutical companies, such as Concert Pharmaceuticals, Auspex Pharmaceuticals, and Zelgen Biopharmaceuticals, have engaged in the research and development of deuterium-labeled drugs, and some typical deuterium-labeled drugs, such as CTP-499, deutero-venlafaxine, and deutero-daparol, have entered the clinical research stage [ 10 ]. The key to the development of deuterated pharmaceuticals lies in the labeling of specific sites of the related drug molecules with deuterium at a high ratio. Thus, the methodologies for precise deuterium incorporation are in the phase of renaissance [ 11–15 ]. In 2018, Atzrodt et al. [ 12 ] reviewed the hydrogen isotope exchange (HIE) strategies for the deuteration of value-added molecules, in which transition metal catalysis has played a critical role. Recently, great efforts are devoted to the development of HIE strategies with site selectivity using metal catalysts for developing effective diagnostics for ADME studies [ 16 ]. The most widely used metal catalysts for isotopic site-selective HIE are Ir(I) complexes developed by Crabtree and Kerr [ 17–20 ]; they enable ortho exchange in the presence of directing groups. Nevertheless, conventional HIEs generally suffer from drawbacks such as the requirement of harsh conditions (e.g., strong acids/bases, high temperature, and flammable gases) and/or multi-exchange processes to ensure high degree of deuterium incorporation. These lead to significant safety risks, undesired deuteration at multiple reactive sites, and poor functional group tolerance. Thus, there is a need to develop new, mild deuteration strategies with wide functional group tolerance and high site selectivity (especially at the metabolic position of drugs), and a sustainable deuterium source. Photo- and electro-catalysis have recently emerged as powerful tools in synthetic chemistry [ 21–25 ], especially for the selective activation of inert chemical bonds under mild conditions [ 26–30 ]. The mild and selective activation of organic molecules to generate reactive radicals, coupled with the ease of activating isotopic reagents such as D2O, has enabled mild and controllable deuteration of chemicals and pharmaceuticals under photo- and electro-catalytic conditions. Thus, this method has risen to the forefront of the field, and the number of research articles on this topic has increased significantly in recent years. Recently, two comprehensive reviews on photocatalytic deuteration methods focusing on the type of deuteration reactions have been published by by Sharma and Cao, respectively [ 31,32 ]. The present article is devoted to reviewing the recent advances in both photo- and electro-catalytic deuteration of fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals (Fig. 1 ). The deuteration strategies are classified according to the deuterium incorporation mode, as follows: (1) Type I: deuterium atom transfer (DAT) strategy, including the generation of reactive radicals followed by deuterium atom transfer using a DAT catalyst (e.g., mercaptan and thiophenol); (2) Type II: deuterium atom abstraction (DAA) strategy in which the reactive species (e.g., radicals and carbanions) generated from photo- or electro-catalytic processes directly abstract deuterium atoms from deuterated solvents; (3) Type III: deuterated water (heavy water) splitting (DWS) strategy, which involves the deuteration or deuterolysis of organic functional groups by the active deuterium species generated in situ from photo- and electro-catalytic heavy water splitting. Mechanistic insights into the generation of reaction species are provided, and the deuterium incorporation and reaction pathways are discussed comprehensively to shed light on the chemistry of photo- and electro-catalytic deuteration processes. Finally, some perspectives on the challenges and future trends are provided to advance the emerging research area of solar- or electrical-energy-driven production of high value-added deuterated chemicals and pharmaceuticals. 2 Photo/electrocatalytic deuteration strategies 2.1 Type I: Photocatalytic DAT strategy Photocatalytic DAT strategies have been widely explored in the preparation of deuterated compounds. They generally include two steps: (1) the generation of reactive radicals and (2) deuterium atom transfer from D2O to the radical using DAT catalysts such as mercaptan or thiophenol. The generation of reactive radicals by photocatalysis can be predominantly classified into single electron transfer (SET), energy transfer (ET), and hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) reactions. Photocatalytic SET refers to the generation of radicals via the single electron reduction or oxidation of the substrate by the excited photocatalyst. However, the redox potential of the substrate should match with that of the photocatalyst. Photocatalytic HAT methods, including direct or indirect methods, rely on the bond strength of the substrate, which can generate free radicals without the limitation of the redox potential. In the direct HAT process, the excited photocatalyst simultaneously abstracts an electron and a proton from the substrate to directly furnish a radical. Ketones or polyoxometalates (e.g., decatungstate anion: [W10O32]4 −) are the most popular HAT photocatalysts. In the indirect HAT process, the hydrogen atom at a specific position of the substrate is abstracted by a hydrogen abstractor, such as a thiol, resulting in the formation of a radical. Although photocatalytic ET has been rarely explored [ 33 ], reactive radicals can be generated by ET from the excited photocatalyst. For a better understanding of the photocatalytic DAT, a schematic illustrating the generation of radicals followed by catalytic DAT is provided in Scheme 1 . 2.1.1 SET-induced generation of central carbon radicals Photocatalytic SET-induced decarboxylation is one of the most widely explored strategies for the formation of carbon radicals [ 34,35 ]. Hatanaka et al. [ 36 ] pioneered the generation of alkyl radicals by the photocatalytic decarboxylation of carboxylic acids using two photosensitizers, phenanthrene (Phen) and 1,4-dicyanobenzene (DCB). Using tert-dodecanethiol as the DAT catalyst and D2O as the deuterium source, deuterated products with mono- or di-deuterium substituents were readily obtained (Scheme 2 ). A high-pressure mercury lamp was still necessary because of the limitation of the absorption wavelength of the photosensitizer. In 2015, Nicewicz et al. [ 37 ] achieved the photocatalytic decarboxylation of carboxylic acids to alkanes using Fukuzumi acridinium photooxidants, which are reported to have excited state reduction potentials of greater than +2.0 V (vs. saturated calomel electrode (SCE)). Thus, many previously inaccessible carboxylic acid substrates such as dicarboxylates (e.g., malonic acid derivatives) were compatible with this transformation under blue LED irradiation. Photocatalytic deoxygenation of carboxylic acids to aldehydes has been rarely reported compared to oxidative decarboxylation owing to the difficulty in the activation of inert C−O bonds of carboxylic acids [ 38 ]. To resolve this issue, Xie et al. [ 39 ] used Ph3P as an O-atom transfer reagent, thus achieving photocatalytic deoxygenative deuteration to directly obtain deuterated aldehydes from aromatic and aliphatic carboxylic acids. As shown in Scheme 3 , a wide range of deuterated aldehydes, including biologically active aromatic and aliphatic molecules, were produced in moderate to good yields with a high degree of deuterium incorporation. The key to this transformation lies in synergistic photoredox catalysis and thiol-based DAT catalysis in conjunction with phosphoranyl radical chemistry, wherein the substrates undergo β-scission to yield a reactive acyl radical and triphenylphosphine oxide as a result of the strong affinity between the phosphine and oxygen atom. Next, the acyl radical undergoes the DAT process in which it abstracts a deuterium atom from deuterated mercaptan to produce the corresponding products. Similarly, based on the strong affinity between phosphines and sulfur atoms, Sun et al. [ 40 ] developed a mild metal-free desulfurization-deuteration method for site-specific deuteration (Scheme 4 ). In this case, the generation of radical was initiated by di-tert-butyl peroxide (DTBP) and Ph2POEt under visible light irradiation at room temperature. Owing to the photocatalyst-free process and mild conditions, this desulfurization-deuteration process exhibits good functional group tolerance and is even compatible with carboxylic acids and alcohols. The generation of carbon radicals via photocatalytic decarboxylation has emerged as a powerful strategy for forming C–C and C-heteroatom (O, S, and N) bonds [ 41 ]. In this context, Studer and Jiang [ 42 ] developed an interesting anti-Markovnikov radical hydroamidation and deuteroamidation of inactivated alkenes to generate carbobenzyloxy (Cbz)-protected primary amines, including β-deuterated amines (Scheme 5 ). This transformation includes two processes: (1) the carboxyl radical formed by the SET oxidation of α-Cbz-amino-oxy carboxylate fragments CO2 and acetone to generate an N-centered radical (CbzHNC); (2) the N-centered radical adds to the terminal position of the alkene to yield the corresponding alkyl radical adduct, which abstracts deuterium and hydrogen by DAT and HAT from PhSD(H), providing the corresponding hydroamidation and deuteroamidation products. As shown in Scheme 5, various β-deuterated amides were prepared in good yields with a high degree of D incorporation, and this is a promising approach for the preparation of high value-added D-labeled bioactive compounds. Photocatalytic dehalogenation of organic halides is another key method for producing carbon radicals via a reduction/activation process. Owing to the limitation of the highly negative reduction potentials of inactivated alkyl and aryl halides (for example, the measured reduction potentials of inactivated alkyl and aryl iodides are more negative than −2.0 V vs. SCE), the photocatalytic reduction of inactivated alkyl and aryl halides by SET is difficult to accomplish. More recently, a photocatalytic system consisting of an aryl-amine photocatalyst and a disulfide co-catalyst had been developed by Gong's group (Scheme 6 ) [ 43 ]. Based on the strong reduction potential of conjugated arylamine photocatalyst (E *ox = −1.61 to −2.71 V vs. SCE), a serious of aryl or alkyl chlorides were converted to deuterated products at mild conditions. In this intriguing transformation process, the authors hold that the aryl amine photocatalyst not only initiate cleavage of the C–Cl bond by SET, but also induce homolysis of the disulfide by ET. Similar to HAT, halogen atom transfer (denoted as XAT) is a bond-energy-dependent activation mode, which has proven to be highly reliable in accessing carbon radicals from organic halides with the use of hazardous reagents such as tributyltin hydride. In 2020, Juliá and Leonori [ 44 ] demonstrated the homolytic activation of inert carbon–halogen bonds with α-aminoalkyl radicals as XAT reagents (Scheme 7 ). Deuteration, cross-electrophile coupling, Heck-type olefination, and aromatic C-H alkylation of iodides and bromides were achieved using the photocatalytic XAT protocol under mild conditions. Moreover, high yields and desired D incorporation were achieved using D2O. This α-aminoalkyl radical-based XAT strategy is also applicable to bromides, albeit with a lower conversion rate compared to that obtained with iodides. Photocatalytic SET oxidation of tertiary amines can easily generate α-amino carbon radicals, which can sequentially participate in different types of coupling reactions. MacMillan et al. [ 45 ] recently developed an excellent method for the efficient and selective incorporation of deuterium and tritium at the α-amino sp 3 C–H bonds by synergistic SET and DAT processes. Using this method, up to 18 N-alkyl amine-based deuterated drug molecules were successfully produced with deuterium incorporated at α-amino sp 3 C–H bonds, along with some other active sites, including benzyl sites (Scheme 8 ). On this basis, Sparr et al. [ 46 ] designed and prepared a new acridine photocatalyst that improved the selectivity of the incorporation of deuterium at aliphatic positions at a low catalyst loading. Peptide drugs play a major role in therapeutic treatment. To prepare deuterated peptide drugs, Derdau et al. [ 47 ] developed a modified MacMillan's method for labeling peptide molecules using an organic base with high pK b. In this approach, the stoichiometry and strength of the base were first optimized to deprotonate the ammonium ion to furnish the free primary amine. Then, the primary amine was oxidized using the photocatalyst to produce α-amino radicals, which abstracted deuterium from a deuterated thioalcohol to furnish the α-deuterated amine product. This reaction was found to be highly selective in the deuteration of a range of amino acids, peptides, and peptide-derived drugs, especially the lysine side chain (Scheme 9 ). 2.1.2 HAT-induced formation of central carbon/silyl radicals Reactive radicals could be generated using photocatalytic HAT strategies via three pathways: direct HAT, indirect HAT, and proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) [ 48 ]. In direct HAT, the photocatalyst itself acts as the HAT catalyst to abstract a H atom from the substrate to form a radical for the sequential transformation. Meanwhile, the indirect HAT process requires an additional HAT reagent, which is generally activated by the excited photocatalyst via SET or ET processes, to initiate the HAT process. The PCET mode involves the concerted transfer of an electron and a proton. In contrast to conventional HAT, protons and electrons could originate from two separate donors or travel to two distinct acceptors in the PCET process. C-1 deuterated aldehydes are valuable deuterated building blocks for the synthesis of deuterated drugs owing to their versatile reactivity. Hydrogen–deuterium exchange with aldehydes is the most straightforward pathway. The generation of formyl radicals by direct or indirect HAT is one of the most economical and effective methods. For example, Wang et al. [ 49 ] and Wu et al. [ 50 ] independently reported the formyl-selective deuteration of aldehydes based on the direct HAT strategy using tetra-n-butylammonium decatungstate (TBADT) as the HAT photocatalyst (Scheme 10 ). A series of deuterated aromatic aldehydes and aliphatic aldehydes were synthesized under 390 nm light irradiation. Notably, Wu's protocol was also effective in the formation of a wide range of hydridic C(sp 3)–H bonds (e.g., α-oxy, α-thioxy, α-amino, benzylic, and inactivated tertiary C(sp 3)–H bonds) with high selectivity and high levels of D incorporation (Scheme 10). Their studies on the reaction scope suggested that both the polarity and the steric effect are important in determining the regioselectivity in TBADT-catalyzed C–H functionalization. The formation of a formyl radical could also be achieved by the indirect HAT strategy using an additional HAT reagent, as demonstrated by Wang et al. [ 51 ] for the facile synthesis of C-1 deuterated aldehydes (Scheme 11 ). In this study, PhCO2Na was used as a precursor for the formation of PhCO2• in the presence of PC. Then, HAT between PhCO2• and aldehyde provided the corresponding formyl radical, which could abstract a deuterium atom from a deuterated thioalcohol, another DAT catalyst, to produce the target C1-deuterated aldehyde in good yield with excellent D incorporation. More recently, Wang's group found that the iPr3SiSH could not only act as a HAT catalyst for producing acyl radicals, but also act as a DAT catalyst by replacing PhCO2Na with Na2CO3 [ 52 ]. Under almost the same conditions, visible-light-mediated deuteration of aldehydes via reversible HAT process was developed. Silane is a mild and efficient reducing agent, which is widely used in the synthesis of drugs and natural products [ 53 ]. In this context, deuterated silanes are versatile reagents for deuterium-labeling compounds prepared. With a rational design, Wu's group reported an unprecedented visible-light-mediated deuteration of silanes using a thioalcohol as both an HAT catalyst for the formation of silyl radicals and a DAT catalyst for transferring deuterium atoms from D2O to silyl radicals, and obtained valuable deuterated silanes with high yields and excellent D incorporation (Scheme 12 ) [ 54 ]. This protocol is effective in the production of a wide range of aryl- and alkyl-substituted silanes. Impressively, a 100 gram-scale production of deuterated triethyl silane was achieved using a continuous-flow micro-tubing reactor system, demonstrating the practical applicability of this strategy. The universal applicability and mildness of the synergetic photocatalysis and DAT catalysis have been well demonstrated in the sustainable synthesis of value-added deuterated feedstock chemicals and drug molecules with D2O as the sustainable D source. The highly promising electrocatalytic DAT strategy, which facilitates reactive radicals by electrocatalytic oxidation or reduction followed by DAT catalysis, has however been rarely explored to date. 2.2 Type II: Photo/electro-catalytic DAA from a deuterated solvent In contrast to the DAT strategy, which involves a DAT catalyst, the DAA strategy refers to the direct abstraction of deuterium from the solvent by reactive species generated in situ, including radicals and anions. The bond dissociation energy (BDE) of the C–D bond in the product against the BDE of the deuterated solvent should be thermodynamically favorable. Thus, deuterated solvents such as deuterated water, deuterated alcohols (e.g., CH3OH-d4 and iPrOH-d8), and deuterated chloroform are the most commonly used deuterium sources. 2.2.1 DAA from solvent by reactive radicals The radical-based DAA strategy also includes two steps: the generation of reactive radicals by photocatalysis or electrocatalysis, followed by DAA from the solvent, as shown in Scheme 13 . Similar to the photocatalytic DAT strategy, the generation of reactive radicals can be achieved by SET, HAT, or ET. Compared to photocatalytic SET and HAT, the application of the ET strategy for deuteration has been rarely reported. Recently, a triplet-triplet ET strategy was revealed for the rapid generation of aryl and alkyl radicals from carboxylic acid esters, as shown in Scheme 14 [ 55 ]. The deuterium atom abstraction from inexpensive deuterated chloroform (used as the solvent) by these aryl and alkyl radicals is thermodynamically favored (BDE of C–H (CHCl3) = 93.8 kcal mol−1 versus BDE of C–H (benzene) = 113.5 kcal mol−1), and thus a variety of aryl and alkyl carboxylic acids, including natural products and drug molecules, were readily converted to the corresponding deuterated products in good yields. Photocatalytic deutero-dehalogenation of organic halides via SET reduction has been well documented as a convenient and effective method for the preparation of deuterated compounds [ 56 ]. However, this strategy is still difficult to apply in the deuteration of inactivated alkyl and aryl halides owing to the high reduction potentials of these inert halides and the relatively narrow redox potential window of the typical photocatalysts [ 57–59 ]. With the aid of a palladium complex, effective photo-induced reductive dehalogenation of inactivated aryl/alkyl bromides and chlorides was achieved by Liang et al. [ 60 ]. In this work, the excited Pd(0) complex induced an SET process of halides through an oxidative quenching cycle under visible light irradiation. Thus, inactive aryl and alkyl halides, especially alkyl bromides and chlorides, could be readily activated to generate the corresponding aryl and alkyl radicals, which sequentially abstracted deuterium atoms from i-PrOH-d8 (Scheme 15 ). The transformation of anilines to arenediazonium salts and the subsequent reductive deuteration by the release of N2 via photocatalytic SET is the most prominent method for the deutero-deamination of aromatic derivatives. Wangelin et al. [ 61 ] developed a green-light-driven deuterodediazonation reaction using eosin as the photocatalyst and DMF-d7 as the D source (Scheme 16 ). Such photocatalyst-free procedures have attracted immense attention in recent years owing to the ease of the carbon radical generation from arenediazonium salts under light irradiation. For example, deutero-deamination of bench-stable, colored arylazo sulfones via visible light irradiation in deuterated media such as isopropanol-d8 or THF-d8/water mixtures under photocatalyst-free conditions was reported by Fagnoni and coworkers (Scheme 16) [ 62 ]. In this study, a dyed-auxiliary group (–N2SO2CH3) was incorporated into diazo compounds, which rendered the arylazo sulfones both colored and photoreactive. In addition, the generation of reactive radicals by electrocatalysis via SET reduction or oxidation is extremely promising for sequential deuteration reactions. Reductive amination is a powerful tool in the synthesis of amine-based pharmaceuticals, because one quarter of the pharmaceuticals are fabricated by reductive amination in one or multiple synthetic steps using a suitable reductant. Alternatively, a sustainable electrochemically induced SET reductive amination was recently achieved by Huang et al. [ 63 ] with the use of DMSO as the solvent and H donor (Scheme 17 ). In the presence of DMSO-d6 as the D donor, a variety of α-position monodeuterated amines were obtained in moderate to high yields with good to excellent D incorporation. A mechanism for this electrochemically induced SET reductive amination was also proposed by the authors: an imine cation was first generated from benzaldehyde and aniline at the cathode and then reduced with an electron to form a radical intermediate, which subsequently abstracted a deuterium atom from DMSO-d6, producing the deuterated amine and a DMSO radical. The DMSO radical was sequentially reduced and re-protonated to DMSO at the cathode. Meanwhile, DMSO was oxidized at the anode with oxygen to provide two electrons. 2.2.2 DAA from solvents by carbanions In addition to carbon radicals, carbanions generated by photocatalysis or electrocatalysis via two successive single electron transfers can spontaneously abstract deuterium atoms from solvents including D2O to form deuterium-labeled compounds, as shown in Scheme 18 . The addition of radical species to double bonds (Giese-type addition) has been exploited for the functionalization of activated alkenes. In general, a radical arising from the photo/electrocatalytic SET or HAT process is added to the unsaturated precursor, resulting in a new carbon radical for the sequential C–C bond or C–H/D bond forming reactions. As a “proof of concept”, Wang et al. [ 64 ] recently reported a mild, versatile organophotoredox protocol for the synthesis of enantio-enriched α-deuterated α-amino acids. As shown in Scheme 19 , firstly, the direct addition of a decarboxylated radical to dehydroalanine derivative resulted in a chiral radical, which subsequently captured a single electron by a photocatalytic SET process to produce a chiral anion intermediate. Then, the Re-face selective deuteration of the chiral anion intermediate by D2O resulted in an enantio-enriched enantio-enriched deuterated product. Using a similar Giese-type reaction, a mild and efficient protocol for the selective deuterium labeling of silicon-containing compounds via photoinduced decarboxylation of silacarboxylic acids was developed by Uchiyama et al. [ 65 ]. Imines generally undergo a photocatalytic SET process to furnish highly reactive radical anion intermediates as electrophiles for sequential radical coupling reactions to form C–C bonds [ 66–68 ]. Recently, a different nucleophilic carbanionic reactivity of ketimine mediated by photoredox catalysis was reported by Walsh and coworkers (Scheme 20 ) [ 69 ]. In this study, a ketimine was first reduced to a radical anion, which was stabilized by resonance forms A and B shown in Scheme 20. Owing to its higher reactivity, resonance form B was rapidly quenched by the Cy2NMe radical cation to form a ketiminyl carbanion intermediate. Subsequently, the umpolung ketiminyl carbanion abstracted deuterium from D2O, affording the final reduced α-deuterated product in excellent yield with high D incorporation. Nevertheless, the need for two aryl groups to stabilize the umpolung ketiminyl carbanion intermediate led to the poor versatility of this protocol. The development of asymmetric catalytic deuteration techniques is critically important for the synthesis of chiral deuterated drugs, but has been rarely reported. Compared with the free-radical-based strategy, asymmetric catalytic deuteration via carbo-cationic or anionic intermediates is more implementable to be achieved [ 70 ]. Recently, an interesting enantioselective reductive dechlorination-deuteration of α-chloro- azaarenes via synergetic photoredox catalysis and Brønsted acid-promoted chiral catalysis was reported [ 71 ]. As shown in Scheme 21 , racemic α-chloro-azaarenes and prochiral azaarene-substituted ketones were first subjected to double single-electron reduction to generate a prochiral carbanion intermediate. Then, benefitting from the enantio-controlling environment originating from the stable hydrogen bond formed with the nitrogen atom of the aza-arene, the carbanion intermediate enantioselectively abstracted a deuterium atom from D2O, yielding the deuterated product with moderate to high enantiomeric excess. Electrochemistry is a promising technique for effectively reducing inert chemical compounds (e.g., inert halides and unsaturated olefins) with high reduction potentials to generate reactive radicals as well as carbanions for cascade deuteration. In this context, Cheng's group [ 72 ] described a strategy for the electrochemical deuteration of α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds without using a catalyst or an additional reductant, thereby demonstrating the excellent functional group tolerance under the reaction conditions (Scheme 22 ). The experimental results indicated that the unsaturated substrate (E red = −2.1 V vs. SCE) rather than D+ was preferentially reduced by the electrons at the carbon cathode. According to the proposed mechanism, the polar double bond undergoes two SET reduction reactions coupled with deuteration at the cathode, while the OD− anion undergoes oxidation to release oxygen and D2O at the anode, as proven by 18O labeling studies. 2.3 Type III: Photo/electrocatalytic DWS Conventional reductive deuteration approaches for deuterating feedstock chemicals and drugs require the use of deuterated reductants such as NaBD4, LiAlD4, or flammable D2 gas. The D substitution is of significant importance, as these reagents are expensive and highly volatile. Photocatalytic and electrocatalytic water splitting for hydrogen evolution has become one of the most promising approaches to produce reductive H species from the mildest reagent, water [ 73–78 ]. By replacing water with heavy water, active D species (adsorbed D denoted as Dad) or D2 generated from heavy water splitting can be incorporated into organic molecules by reductive deuteration or deuterogenolysis (Scheme 23 ). 2.3.1 Deuteration with active deuterium species generated by heavy water splitting In 2018, Su's group [ 56 ] reported a pioneering study on the photocatalytic water splitting technology to generate active D species for the controllable deuteration of halides over porous CdSe nanosheets. A variety of organic iodides and activated bromides, chlorides, and fluorides were found to be compatible with this strategy, and could be effectively deuterated in excellent yields with high levels of D incorporation and good functional group tolerance (Scheme 24 ). The high reduction potential of the porous CdSe consisting of a nanocrystalline domain and the presence of unsaturated coordination Cd sites at a high density critically contributed to the high catalytic performance. This strategy allows the incorporation of a controllable number of deuterium atoms at specific sites on the substrate and is comparable to the current C–H/C–D exchange technology, thus opening the pathway for further studies on the usage of heavy water splitting technology for controllable deuteration. Soon after, Su's group [ 79 ] further developed a sub-micrometer Pd nanosheet (Pd NS)-decorated crystalline K cation-intercalated polymeric carbon nitride (KPCN) for the specific activation of C–Cl. The high atom utilization ratio and specific surface area of the Pd NS could increase the contact area between Pd and KPCN, thus facilitating electron transfer at the interface and enhancing the adsorption of the photogenerated active D species and chloride substrates. A variety of aryl and heteroaryl chlorides were effectively deuterated under mild conditions in remarkable yields with good functional group tolerance. Inspired by these studies, Xie et al. [ 80 ] accomplished the same transformation using plasmonic Au/CdS as the photocatalyst in 2019. Recently, using the heavy water splitting strategy, Wu's group [ 81 ] described the reduction of a range of aromatic ketones to deuterium-labeled diaryl-alcohols via CdSe quantum dots photocatalysis (Scheme 25 ). Owing the low reduction potential of aromatic ketones, the aromatic ketones were directly reduced to diaryl carbon radicals by photoelectrons firstly. Then the coupling of deuterium radicals originated from D2O splitting with diaryl carbon radicals furnished the deuterated products with good yields and high-level of D-incorporation. It could be predicted that electrocatalytic heavy water splitting could emerge as another promising approach for the controllable deuteration of organic compounds, including halides, under mild conditions. More remarkably, this technique enables precise reductive deuteration by the fine-tuning of the applied voltage according to the electrochemical window. Almost synchronously, Su [ 82 ], Zhang [ 83 ], and Lei's [ 84 ] groups developed an electrocatalytic strategy for the deuteration of organic halides using a homogeneous palladium catalyst, copper nanowire array cathode, and Pt(+) || Pb(−) electrode system, respectively (Scheme 26 ). Su et al. [ 82 ] demonstrated the electrochemical deuteration of organic halides (RI, RBr, and RCl) with two graphite electrodes (cathode with Pd loading) and Na2SO4 as the electrolyte. They systematically investigated the Faraday efficiency, effect of pH, recyclability of D2O, and electrocatalytic mechanism. Importantly, they demonstrated that the efficiency and selectivity of the reaction and the substitution of deuterium atoms at different halogen positions can be precisely controlled by tuning the applied voltage, guided by the electrochemical window. Finally, the gram-scale synthesis of deuterated pharmaceuticals confirmed the practical applicability of this protocol. Zhang and coworkers [ 83 ] reported the electrochemical deuterodehalogenation of halides (RI and RBr) using a copper nanowire array (NWA) cathode under basic conditions using K2CO3 as the electrolyte. A one-pot halogenation-deuterodehalogenation of the original C–H bonds to C–D bonds was achieved with good yields and high deuterium incorporation. Lei and coworkers [ 84 ] employed an electrochemical system with a platinum plate (anode) and lead plate (cathode) as the electrodes and nBu4NBF4 as the electrolyte combined with NPh3 or PPh3 as the additive for the deuteration of (hetero)aryl halides (RI, RBr, and RCl) with a wide reaction scope. The reaction mechanism was revealed through radical trapping and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments. The protocol was realized using cheap and common batteries and electrodes, without using any metal catalysts, external reductants, or toxic reagents. Apart from achieving halide-deuterium exchange with D2O, Su and coworkers [ 85 ] expanded the photocatalytic heavy water splitting technology for the controllable deuteration of alkenes and alkynes. KPCN anchored with a Pd nanoparticle catalyst was designed and utilized as a bifunctional photocatalyst, wherein KPCN acted as a superior photocatalyst compared to its PCN counterpart without K+, while Pd acted as a cocatalyst in the production of D2/Dad and a transition metal catalyst in the catalytic deuteration of alkenes and alkynes (Scheme 27 ). The deuteration of alkenes and alkynes provides a promising route for the selective incorporation of deuterium atoms in C(sp 3)–D bonds of fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals using D2O as the most inexpensive and sustainable D source under mild conditions. Furthermore, an electrochemical strategy based on heavy water splitting for the selective deuteration of C=C and C≡C bonds was recently realized by Berlinguette [ 86 ] and Zhang's groups [ 87 ], respectively (Scheme 27). Berlinguette and coworkers [ 86 ] reported the deuteration of various unsaturated compounds such as alkynes (C≡C), alkenes (C=C), aldehydes (C=O), and imines (C=N) using a tandem electrochemical palladium membrane reactor using D2O at room temperature and ambient pressure. The compartmentalized reactor facilitated the adsorption of deuterium atoms onto the Pd foil and subsequent diffusion from the other side. Thus, it was compatible with various solvents in the chemical compartment and enabled the reuse of D2O without purification. Remarkably, the deuteration rates and chemoselective formation of C(sp 2)–D and C(sp 3)–D bonds could be easily controlled by changing the applied current. Zhang et al. [ 81 ] focused on the semi-deuteration of alkynes using a Pd-P alloy cathode under basic conditions. They synthesized a series of deuterated alkenes with a high Z-alkene selectivity of up to 99%. Impressively, mono-, di-, and tri-deuterated alkenes with specific deuterated sites were achieved. With rational design, a synergistic system could be achieved on the basis of the heavy water splitting technology toward the synthesis of more complex deuterated molecules related to pharmaceuticals. For example, Su et al. [ 88 ] recently described photocatalytic heavy water splitting (catalyzed by a semiconductor) coupled with isotopic alkanol oxidation by photoexcited electron-hole pairs to achieve the sustainable production of deuterated N-alkyl pharmaceuticals (Scheme 28 ). In this method, the photoexcited electrons were first transferred to surface-anchored Pd nanoparticles, and then utilized to split water to furnish absorbed [H]/[D] species. Simultaneously, the photogenerated holes were utilized to selectively oxidize isotopic alkanols to generate the corresponding aldehyde intermediates for sequential aldehyde–amine condensation to furnish the imine intermediates. Subsequently, the imines were reduced by [H]/[D] derived from water splitting to obtain corresponding N-alkyl chemicals and drugs. Remarkably, the number of deuterium atoms (N-CD3, CD2H, and CDH2) at the potential metabolic positions of N-Me drugs can be precisely controlled by simply tuning the proportions of isotopic water and methanol. Finally, a number of important deuterated N-alkyl pharmaceuticals and late-stage functionalized drugs were synthesized, highlighting the universal applicability and mildness of this strategy. 2.3.2 Deuteration with D2 produced in situ by heavy water splitting The state-of-the-art transition-metal-catalyzed deuteration using D2 gas is still a powerful strategy with high atom economy for the production of deuterated feedstock chemicals and pharmaceuticals. However, the main drawbacks include the safety risks associated with the usage of flammable hydrogen/deuterium gas, which can explode easily, especially under harsh synthetic conditions (high temperature and/or high pressure). Therefore, it is highly desirable to control the supply of D2 by heavy water splitting for transition-metal-catalyzed deuteration under very mild conditions to synthesize deuterated drugs and their building blocks. With this protocol, D2O could be the ideal D source instead of the expensive and flammable D2 gas for a variety of mild transition-metal-catalyzed deuteration reactions [ 89–91 ]. In this context, Su et al. [ 92 ] reported the first palladium-catalyzed room-temperature deuterogenolysis of carbon–oxygen bonds in alcohols and ketones for producing deuterated pharmaceuticals (Scheme 29 ). Taking advantage of the mild conditions, they designed a reactor consisting of a chemical compartment and an electrochemical compartment connected with a cannula. Then, they supplied the D2 gas generated in situ by the electrocatalytic splitting of D2O to the chemical compartment for the on-demand Pd-catalyzed deuterogenolysis at room temperature and normal pressure. With this synergistic system, the ibuprofen precursor was synthesized on a gram scale in a sustainable and practical manner using D2O as the D source. 3 Conclusions and outlook Herein, we overviewed the recent advances in photo/electrocatalytic deuteration strategies, classified as DAT, DAA, and DWS strategies. Under these categories, many promising transformations including the C–H/C–D exchange in inert C(sp 3)–H and C(sp 2)–H bonds, selective and controllable C–X/C–D exchange, precise deutero-defunctionalization, and catalytic reductive deuteration based on D2O splitting, and the related catalytic mechanisms were outlined. The mild conditions, good tolerance of functional groups to the reaction conditions, precise site selectivity, and high degree of D incorporation render these strategies advantageous in the production of a wide range of deuterated feedstock chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and natural products. Despite the tremendous achievements, several issues still need to be addressed, and the future opportunities and challenges might depend on the following aspects: (1) the development of an innovative strategy for asymmetric catalytic deuteration toward the production of chiral deuterated drugs. At present, asymmetric catalytic deuteration under mild conditions, especially with the circumvention of the use of flammable D2, is highly desired but has been rarely reported. Establishing synergistic deuteration systems for photo/electrocatalysis with chiral catalysis or enzymatic catalysis is one of the potential approaches to overcome this challenge. (2) Mild and precise substitution of deuterium at the metabolic positions of drugs to improve their biological activities. For example, amine is a core structural motif found in many medicinal agents and bioactive alkaloids [ 93–96 ]. In fact, N-α-dehydrogenation metabolized cytochrome P450 is commonly found in N-containing drugs and other bioactive molecules. Further, substitution of hydrogen in α-amino acids with deuterium is expected to slow the N–C bond cleavage and impact their pharmacodynamic properties and improve pesticidal effects. Thus, the reductive deuteration of amides and cyano derivatives may be the most appropriate and direct method for preparing α-deuterated amines. At present, although conventional methods that use sodium or samarium diiodide as a single electron reductant have realized these transformations, the requirement for a strong reducing agent and inconvenient operation limit their further application. In the future, a possible way to promote these transformations is to utilize the green and highly active hydrogen species generated from photo/electrocatalytic water splitting as the reductant and D donor for the production of α-deuterated amines. Thus, it is very important to design and improve the existing photocatalytic materials for those transformations [ 97–100 ]. In addition, from the perspective of medicinal chemistry, the introduction of a methyl group at an appropriate position in the molecule can significantly change the efficacy of the pharmaceutical, which is referred to as the magic methyl effect, which is one of the most widely used strategies to modify bioactive compounds. It can be predicted that the trideuteromethyl group can be more magical than the methyl group. The conventional thermocatalytic introduction of trideuteromethyl group mainly relies on expensive and highly toxic (CD3)2SO4 and CD3I as deuterium sources. MacMillan and coworkers recently reported the use of metallaphotoredox aryl and alkyl radiomethylation for Positron emission tomography (PET) ligand discovery [ 101 ], but the radiomethyl source is either a specialized/non-commercialized organic molecule or an expensive/toxic iodide. Thus, more efforts should be devoted to the development of photo/electrocatalytic deuteration methods using simple and commercially available deuterated methyl sources, such as CD3OD. Finally, with the rapid development of advanced photo/electrocatalysts and smart deuteration strategies, the emergence of a new horizon for the precise production of useful deuterated feedstock chemicals and drugs can be envisioned. coredata.dc:description: Deuterium labeling techniques are widely utilized as efficient tools to study the absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion (ADME) of pharmaceuticals. Moreover, deuterium-labeled drugs are expected to prolong the half-life of drug metabolism, enhance the efficacy of drugs, close metabolic sites, and decrease side effects. Thus, there is a rising demand for the practical construction of deuterium-labeled drugs and their intermediates under mild conditions. This paper timely provides an overview of the recent advances in both photo- and electro-catalytic mild and selective deuteration of fine chemicals and pharmaceuticals with low-cost and sustainable deuterium source. Three types of deuteration strategies are discussed according to the deuteration mode, named deuterium atom transfer strategy, deuterium atom abstraction strategy and deuterated water splitting strategy respectively. The application scope and mechanistic insights are discussed comprehensively. Finally, the perspective on the challenges and future development trends for photo- and electro-catalytic deuteration strategies are also presented.
